subject: Relationships
title: Marriage in Ancient Rome
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Marriage in Ancient Rome.

hook.text: Roman marriage came in two forms: one where the wife became her husband's property, one where she stayed free.

buildup.text: 'Cum manu' marriage transferred a woman to her husband's family. 'Sine manu' let her keep her father's family rights.

discovery.text: By the late Republic, 'sine manu' dominated. Roman women increasingly demanded autonomy within marriage.

twist.text: Romans could divorce by simply declaring it. No courts, no clergy. 'I no longer wish to be married.' Done.

climax.text: Roman marriage was surprisingly flexible. It evolved with social pressure â€” just as marriage does today.

punchline.text: Romans divorced by declaration. Marriage was a contract, not a sacrament.

quiz.question: What was 'sine manu' marriage in Rome?
options: Marriage where the wife became property
Marriage where the wife kept her family rights
